newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch PM opposes "pre-selection" of EMU members.
newsitem.headline: Dutch PM opposes "pre-selection" of EMU members.

text.p: Dutch Prime Minister Wim Kok said on Tuesday he opposed any "pre-selection" of members of European economic and monetary union (EMU).
Kok said EMU membership should be determined solely on the basis of EU member states' performance in 1997.
The selection would be made early in 1998 and there should be no "pre-selection" or "speculation" before then, he said.
Kok was speaking at a joint news conference with Spanish Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar.
"I am a declared opponent of any pre-selection on the basis of any kind of prejudices or bias," Kok said.
The Dutch prime minister said EMU membership would be decided according to an objective application of the convergence criteria laid out in the Maastricht Treaty.
"There is no point in politicians making comparisons between countries or making speculative predictions," he said.
Kok added that countries who wanted to be among the first wave of EMU members would need to have their economies and public finances in a good structural condition.
"Taking a pill to suppress your fever for a day, when you know you're not really healthy -- that is not a good condition."
Kok was speaking after more than two hours of talks with Aznar about European Union and bilateral issues.
The Netherlands holds the European Union presidency in the first half of 1997 and hopes to draft a treaty on EU reform in time for it to be signed at a June summit in Amsterdam.
